content.body: I had a good time at the TPAC - granted the most fun was the night we all went out for mexican food
i'm not arguing that they're not fun, especially the first few
i'm arguing that they're a waste of time
i do think we should have some get togethers more often
it's hard with us spread around so much though

I was watching the documentary Code Rush - about Mozilla and noticed that they all have a celebration dinner at the same mexican restaurant that we all ate at. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u404SLJj7ig -
yup
la fiesta
i first learnt of la fiesta while interning at netscape
we went there all the time
wow - you were at netscape - interesting
bet that was a wild ride
cardona507: i was there for a year as an intern, basically during the netscape 6.0 release
summer 2000 to summer 2001
just before the bubble burst
or as the bubble was bursting
depending on your outlook
any obvious similarities between then and now?
hard to say
the french have a saying, le plus ca change, le plus c'est la meme chose (modulo my not having entered appropriate accents)
which applies here
the fundamentals are all pretty much the same
even the players are pretty much the same
though with some new faces, and some old ones gone
well said
Hixie: The english speaking world has that saying too.  (I dunno where it originated, but it's common now.)
comes from Jean-Baptiste Alphonse Karr

this is slightly OT, but does anyone know where apple was going to publish the FaceTime spec yesterday?
there are so many standards bodies.  i haven't seen anything posted on IETF
anyone know if a css spec indicates i can legally mix hex notation with rgba or not?
paul_irish: Mix how? In the same stylesheet, or the same value?
well my usecase here is a linear gradient..
i can't think of any spec'd things that accept multiple colors like gradients do...
the problem is webkit doesnt allow a mix of hex and rgba values in a linear gradient definition, and i wanted to see if a spec indicates it should.
I guess that would depend on the specification for the property
E.g. https://developer.mozilla.org/en/CSS/-moz-linear-gradient doesn't say anything about the different <color> instances having to use the same syntax, so it should work in firefox
paul_irish: A <color> is a <color> is a <color>.  It doesn't matter what notation you use, even for multiple occurences in one "value" like a linear-gradient() function.
They all just get passed to the color parser and turned into a 4-byte number anyway.
If webkit seriously doesn't allow mixed notations in color-stops in their -webkit-gradient() notation, that's extremely odd.  It would be substantially more work to disallow it than to allow it.

At rendering time I am just replacing the innerHTML of a blank page. This is obviously not sufficient as the style etc are not applied properly and page is distorted.... The question is more how can i retrieve the style of the...
...page so I may store it onto the database?? ....
and then apply it back
Never mind I think I got it....

hey guys. a little question. If i have a widget in my sidebar that has a h1 should it then be a <article> or <section>
henrikbjorn: is the widget 'standalone'?
its a ul with links to discussions
which dosent really have anything to do with the content areas content
sounds like an <aside> then :)
okay :) another stupid question then. What if it is a box width text like "Help us out with feedback click here" aside aswell ?
sure. or you could have an <aside> that wraps all such boxes
oh oh stupid question time? perfect! :)
one from me; the reason for the change from block/inline to flow/phrasing was the confusion once CSS display values are added to the mix, right?
boblet: yes
henrikbjorn: I like to think of <aside> as something that’s not essential to the main content, i.e. something a mobile browser could choose to not download to save bandwidth
zcorpan_: thanks :) thought I remember reading that somewhere but wanted to check
henrikbjorn: you could also use Safari Reader or Instapaper as a mental model
zcorpan_: yeah but the question is what the markup for the box it self should be not the sidebar :)
like iphone specific sites
henrikbjorn: i'd say <section>
i guess a box like this falls under "The section element represents a generic document or application section…"
thanks guys :D
henrikbjorn: if you need more feedback a code sample is always easy to advise on
(not required of course :) )
yeah was just initial thoughts before starting coding. Im sure ill come up with a few questions incl. code samples later on :)

hixie removed it at the same time as the codec big-issue paragraph was removed, citing the fact that all browsers were going to support wave anyway
right...
Hmm, doesn't the W3C testsuite license grant a strict subset of the rights granted by the 3 clause BSD license?
Oh it's probably about whether you get to mention the W3C or not
In one case you have to, in the other you can't
It's relatively hard to grant a superset of the right granted by the 3-clause BSD license without going into trademark territory
*rights
Yeah, I think the trademark issue is the only difference
That is, if you want to mention the W3C you must use the things under the W3C testsuite license which doesn't allow modifications
"Here is a testsuite completely unrelated to w3c"
google chrome doesn't support PCM WAVE
what is the point again of having two licenses for a test? http://www.w3.org/html/wg/wiki/Testing/Submission/
one being less permissive than the other
annevk: the less permissive one is more Official
so basically for people that would love to use it under that license so they are forced to meet the extra requirements?
for people who want to pass the Official Test Suite, I guess

I just added textarea to the rationale page on the wiki: http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Rationale#textarea --> any comments?

TabAtkins, dairy+fish is fine, only dairy+meat/poultry is a problem.  Kosher food isn't quite a subset of vegan food; although all the ingredients in vegan food are kosher, there are some restrictions on the preparation and handling of food that could be a problem even if none of the ingredients are inherently non-kosher.
For instance, milk is a problem according to some if not produced under Jewish supervision.  Grape juice/wine can be a problem.  Some cooked food is a problem.
Something like raw fruit or vegetables should always be fine, at least if you ignore the problem of bugs.
"Problem"?
I mean, it can be non-kosher.
Bugs can be non-kosher?
All bugs are non-kosher, except theoretically some species of locust.
Ah, kk.
The only kosher animals are beasts with cloven hooves that chew their cud, fish with fins and scales, and most birds that people actually eat.

Oh, no.  Just tiny food animal.
